hints_html:
If you believe the statement is true, you need to show that for any two polynomials the limit is always either 0 or \(\displaystyle \pm \infty\).

If you believe the statement is false, you must give one example of two polynomials f and g where the limit is neither 0 nor \(\displaystyle \pm \infty\).

When trying these types of problems, it is always a good idea to try a few examples out first before trying to solve the problem just to get a feeling of what is required.

Remember that the infinite limit of a function gives its horizontal asymptotes. Is it possible for a function \(f(x)/g(x)\) to have a horizontal asymptote NOT at \(0\)?

hints_raw:
If you believe the statement is true, you need to show that for any two polynomials the limit is always either 0 or <math> \displaystyle \pm \infty </math>.

If you believe the statement is false, you must give one example of two polynomials ''f'' and ''g'' where the limit is neither 0 nor <math> \displaystyle \pm \infty </math>.

When trying these types of problems, it is always a good idea to try a few examples out first before trying to solve the problem just to get a feeling of what is required.
Remember that the infinite limit of a function gives its horizontal asymptotes.  Is it possible for a function <math>f(x)/g(x)</math> to have a horizontal asymptote NOT at <math>0</math>?
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
The statement is false. Let’s take polynomials that not only have a nonzero horizontal asymptote but that also always obtain their asymptote! We can choose constant functions for f and g (these are polynomials!) So suppose that \(\displaystyle f(x) = g(x) = 1\). Then, the limit becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{1} = 1\end{aligned}\]

which is not 0 and does not diverge to \(\pm \infty\).

Note: If, for some reason, you don’t like constant polynomials there is a whole zoo of non-constant polynomials f and g with quotients approaching any horizontal asymptote you want, e.g.

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{17x+1}{x} = 17.\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Determine whether each statement is true. If it is, explain why; if not, give a counter-example.

Given polynomials \(f(x)\) and g(x),

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}\end{aligned}\]

is equal to 0, \(\infty\) or \(-\infty\).
